I've never had a Roku before. This is well priced for what you get and the streaming is good quality. There are a few big caveats, though.The first is that Roku try to trick you into putting in a credit card. As you first sign up, the interface gives you no option to avoid this (!), but it actually isn't necessary to function. You have to stop your registration at the point they ask and restart the roku. Then, just log into the website. Works fine without the CC.  I guess marketing thought it was a good idea to force customers to give payment info.  It is kind of scummy.The second is that search is lousy.  Search within individual channels is awkward, and the main Roku search interface doesn't differentiate between movies on channels you already have, and movies on new channels they want you to subscribe to.  By mixing them all, they try to force you to sign up for more channels, I suppose, but it is at the cost of a easy to use search function.The third is that there is no general history or resume. If you stop in the middle of a movie there is no indication when you turn the machine back on of what you were watching or where you stopped. You have to remember to go back into whatever channel you were in, and look for the specific movie again.  Remembering current status is basic functionality, and the whole thing is made worse if you have more channels as Roku encourages.  Surely Roku could figure out how to resume properly. I purchased this for my elderly parents, all this lack of basic function makes their lives considerably more complicated. It is a shame, since those things would be so easy to do right and the streaming itself is fabulous.

This Roku Streaming Stick + has been a royal PITA since I first got it. First of all was the multiple instances in which I had to log in with a username and password just to get access to the various apps. I could understand being required to do this perhaps once for each app (to register for each service), but not multiple times for the same app. I am in the comfort and security of my own home on a password protected (automatic entry for all my devices ALL DAY EVERY DAY) wifi system. I am not worried about hackers or otherwise unauthorized use of their streaming service. Nor should Roku.Undoubtedly, the Fast Forward and Rewind functions are the most aggravating and infurating things about the service, or lack thereof. Both are either too slow or way too fast. And the 10 second rewind function (why no 10 second FFWD option-ignorant!) no longer works. It will freeze the picture and after a 10 second delay or so, it will pick up right back where you left off, with no rewind. And ostensibly, it should be additive, such that if I press this button 5 times, it will go back 50 seconds. But it doesn't do so. And trying to find your way back to a scene you missed for whatever reason is maddening. It takes the patience of a monk to endure the slowest rewind speed. And there is no rational progression beyond that for the next increments of FFWD or REW speeds. It goes into hyper drive on the second push, what is typically reserved for the 3rd or 4th press of the button. Moreover, I have encountered too many disruptions of service where the picture freezes during buffering. To top it all off, customer service is a nightmarish merry-go-round to get through.Don't waste your money. The Amazon firestick does not put me/you through any of this mess, delivers consistent performance, offers both a 10 second rewind AND forwarding function, does not make you log in multiple times (only had to do so twice; one other for Sling subscription initiation), has only frozen in buffering once or twice for less than 10 seconds each time and has a better interface (which helps you find the shows you'd be interested in quicker). Moreover, Amazon customer service is excellent and readily available for help. I had one instance in which I allowed their technician active X remote control. He quickly, quietly and politely resolved the problem. I WILL NEVER BUY ANOTHER ROKU DEVICE AS LONG AS I LIVE!!! I AM GOING TO STICK THIS POS ON A TV I RARELY USE, OR SELL IT TO SOMEONE ELSE AND LET THEM DEAL WITH IT!

Been using this for about a week now and overall I am really happy with it, but becareful of overheating and bandwidth use if your ISP is capped (mine is capped to 1.2TB per month which I need for other stuff too besides roku)Because of the overheating I had to add a fan near it and it dropped the temp from 82c to 66c in the secret screen (see pictures)to access the secret screen to see the temp hit this remote key combo:Home, Home, Home, Home, Home, Fast Forward, Pause, Rewind, Pause, Fast ForwardFor the bandwidth control you will want to go into your Router Settings (see last picture) and enable Traffic Management (QoS) and adjust the downstream to just enough for the Resolution you want to stream at, for me I use 1080p, and 3mbps down is just enough for 1080p streaming and I been able to stay around 15 to 20GB a day (0.5 to 0.8GB per hour) (450 to 600GB per month)Another thing you can do to save bandwidth is go into Roku Settings > Privacy > Advertising and check the box on "Limit Ad Tracking" and then restart the roku stick to apply the settingHave fun, hope this review was helpful

This works great for wireless connection and picture quality, but...1) The stick does not support IR (Infrared) communication. It will only use RF (Radio Freq) communication, so you are locked into using this remote (or a universal remote that supports RF). I watch more than just the Roku, so I need to change the input on my TV. The Roku stick+ will NOT allow you to do change input on your TV.2) Be aware, there is a scam! If you try to connect more than 2 Roku devices from your home and get the "003 error". If you call the number shown, they will give you some BS story about paying anywhere from $70 to $150 to get it connected. Hang up! Go to the settings on your Roku and reset the stick. It will give you a new valid ID.I returned the Stick+ and purchased the Roku Ultra. The Ultra supports IR and login via your computer to your existing Roku account when you setup your new Roku.

I bought this streaming stick specifically to take with me when I travel. I stay in a lot of hotels and some of them don't have smart TVs. For the ones that do, I don't want them to store my credentials for streaming services.  Having read the reviews and thinking I had done my research, I was confident I made the right choice with the Roku streaming stick. It sounded ideal for my situation, but it turns out connecting to the hotel wifi is a disaster with this thing.I'll preface this with saying I'm an IT consultant and have an extensive background setting up many wireless devices. I've tried 2 different Marriotts in two different states and the method of connecting the device to authenticate simply doesn't work when it requires loading a webpage. I ended up having to connect my laptop to the hotel wifi, enable the hotspot feature, and connect the roku to that in order to work. In other words, I have to have my laptop on if I want the roku to work at all times. It's advertised as a standalone device that can do this by itself.What this device needs is a way to directly open the authentication webpage for hotel wifi directly in the roku interface instead of the method of connecting to the roku via wifi and trying to complete all the steps before the connection troubleshooter turns off the roku access point. It times out too quickly to finish the steps. I tried with 3 different devices: My laptop, phone, and tablet. Each time, the roku timed out the connection before the steps could be completed.I realize not all people are in my situation where they need to travel often. Connecting to your home network is easy and the device works well when it does connect, but having it advertised as working easily with hotel wifi networks that authenticate with a webpage is misleading. I'm planning on using a firestick instead for travel.

For the money, Roku has the greatest palette of apps - HBOMax, Apple TV and so many more. However, they appear to have equipped this Streaming Stick+ with the cheapest, weakest WiFi receiver possible. We have high-speed Spectrum cable internet, and our router is right in the living room with our TV, about 12 feet away. All our devices (computer, iPad, phones, etc.) show full bars anywhere in that room, and the LG OLED TV itself has no trouble getting a strong signal on any other app - Netflix, Prime Video, etc.Yet the Roku stick, plugged into the HDMI port on the side of the TV, showed a weak connection of only 3 out of 5 bars, and buffered miserably upon watching. Moving the router within 5’ got us up to 4 bars and less connection glitches. Late last year I broke my 1080p tv. Luckily was able to get a brand new 4k tv a few months later. At first I thought since it was a 4k smart tv I could watch 4k movies. Man was I wrong. Learned only select devices can no matter the tv. So I knew it was time for a new Roku player (had a gen 1 so didn't look good even on 4k). After shopping around and asking questions I went with the Roku streaming stick+. I love it. It even makes non 4k movies and shows look amazing. For the price its so worth it. I was nervous at first because I read my 4k tv needed hdcp 2.2 hdmi outlets or else at best would be 1080p and I couldn't find anything in the manual and behind the tv to say it did. But found out through research my tv did.What is also nice is the fact its not a box, its a stick that goes into a hdmi port (rather then hdmi cable connecting the two) so less clutter on the shelf. Also you don't need to aim the remote directly at it to use it. You can be in front of a wall and it would work. So no need to worry about where you stick it in the tv (for me the hdmis were behind the tv and not on the side).  It is your typical Roku player, has the same apps as the first gen plus any 4k apps (there is a section for it). Also some of the apps (Netflix, hulu) looks completely different then their older model counterparts so had to get used to it.The remote is your standard Roku. Same set up with some very nice features. If you sync it to your tv you can turn off the tv without tv remote and even control the volume (volume controls are on the side) so makes it easier versus using two remotes. A very nice feature is audio control. Kind of like siri or alexxa.. You push the button and make a command to open an app or search for a movie, show or app.Overall the pros are great and cons are nothing to worry about. Id do some research before buying to make sure your tv has the right hdmi ports or else you spent more money on the same thing as a cheap model for non 4k tvs. Defiantly recommend.Pros:-amazing picture for both 4k and hd-No box-don't need to aim remote at device-price-remote features-voice controlCons:-needs a specific hdmi for it to work-some apps are different then the ones on other Roku models

If you stream through a high end home theater system, be aware that Roku and PLEX do not support much more than basic 5.1 channel surround.  This is a problem for audiophiles but no biggie for others.(ABOUT this Roku vs others)-  we bought it for traveling.  It plugs into hotel TVs easily.  Make sure to call the hotel’s tech support and they will register the Roku’s MAC address (found on the back of the Roku stick) so it will connect to WiFi.Finally the remote can control your TV. This has been a common complaint for some time now and I’m so happy it’s finally an included feature.  This makes it easy for the kids to navigate the hotel TV and we don’t have to use the nasty public remote.The only con, and it should be expected, is speed. Menus are still responsive and navigation is fine but actual loading times is noticeably slower.Still the best “cord cutting” device out there vs FireTV/AppleTV/etc.  This is also a worthy upgrade over the older streaming stick with the improved video quality and universal remote.Update:  We took it to Disney and did not have to register the MAC address.
